金砖国家经济增长速度有多快？该视频凸显了金砖国家相对于七国集团的快速崛起。

动画图表：G7 vs. BRICS by GDP (PPP)后的动画图表首先出现在Visual Capitalist上。

;

动画图表：七国集团与金砖国家的 GDP（购买力平价）

五十年前，英国、西德、法国和美国的政府财政负责人在白宫底层图书馆举行非正式会议，讨论当时的国际货币形势。这就是G7的起源故事。

这个最初的集团迅速扩大，加入了日本、意大利和加拿大，巩固了当时最大的非共产主义经济体的集团。作为从战后生产力繁荣中获益的工业化国家，它们是经济巨头，七国集团的经济产出历史上占全球 GDP 的40%左右。

然而，最近出现的另一个国际集团金砖国家（巴西、俄罗斯、印度、中国和南非）一直在全球经济秩序中开辟自己的一部分。

James Eagle的这部动画使用了国际货币基金组织 ( IMF ) 的数据，并绘制了七国集团和金砖国家成员对世界经济的贡献百分比图表。具体来说，它使用的是根据国际美元的购买力平价（PPP）调整后的GDP。

描绘金砖国家与七国集团的崛起

“金砖四国”这个缩写词是由高盛经济学家吉姆·奥尼尔于 2001 年提出的，用于识别处于相似发展阶段的四个快速增长的经济体。直到 2009 年，两国领导人才会面并正式确定关系，并于 2010 年邀请南非加入。

俄罗斯当时也是七国集团成员，后来是八国集团成员。它于1997年受邀加入，但在2014年吞并克里米亚后被驱逐。

虽然金砖国家最初为了投资机会而联合起来，但在过去十年中，金砖国家已成为七国集团的经济竞争对手。他们的几项举措包括建立一家替代性全球银行，并就支付系统和新储备货币进行对话。

以下是按购买力平价调整后这两个集团对世界经济的贡献的快速浏览。

全球 GDP 份额1992年2002年2012年2022年
金砖国家16.45% 19.34% 28.28% 31.67%
G7 45.80% 42.34% 32.82% 30.31%

金砖国家崛起的一个主要因素是中国和印度的经济增长。

经过20世纪80年代和90年代的快速工业化时期，中国的出口在2001年加入世界贸易组织后得到了显着的增长，这帮助中国在2010年成为世界第二大经济体。

印度的经济崛起并不像中国那么迅速，但到2022年，该国将以12万亿美元的国内生产总值（PPP）排名第三。两国合计占世界经济经购买力平价调整后 164 万亿美元的近四分之一。

使用购买力平价指标（更好地反映当地货币和当地价格的优势）的结果是，它对发展中国家的国内生产总值产生巨大的乘数效应，因为这些国家的国内商品和服务的价格往往更便宜。

下面我们可以看到七国集团和金砖国家2023年的名义GDP和按购买力平价调整后的GDP。名义GDP以美元为单位，按市场汇率货币换算，调整后的GDP则使用国际美元（以美国为基准国）以便更好地考虑生活成本和通货膨胀。

国家/组别会员资格名义国内生产总值（2023年）购买力平价国内生产总值（2023年）
我们G7 $26.9吨$26.9吨
日本G7 $4.4T $6.5T
德国G7 $4.3T $5.6T

根据国际货币基金组织的预测，按购买力平价调整后的国内生产总值，金砖国家在 2023 年在世界经济中的占比（56 万亿美元）将超过七国集团（52 万亿美元）。

金砖国家和G7未来如何比较？

中国和印度正处于生产力、工资和消费不断提高的 经济发展阶段，而七国集团大多数国家在二战后的三十年里都曾享受过这样的待遇。

国际货币基金组织预计，到 2028 年，金砖国家将占全球经济的三分之一（购买力平价）：

国家/地区 GDP（购买力平价）会员资格% 世界经济 (2028p)
我们G7 14.5%
日本G7 3.3%
德国G7 2.9%
英国G7 2.1%
法国G7 2.0%
意大利G7 1.7%
加拿大G7 1.3%
中国金砖国家19.7%
印度金砖国家8.6%
俄罗斯金砖国家2.6%
巴西金砖国家2.2%
南非金砖国家0.5%
G7总计27.8%
金砖国家合计33.7%

金砖国家与世界？

金砖国家的经济崛起也带来了地缘政治影响。

除了不同的政治理想之外，金砖国家不断增强的实力也为其成员国提供了财政实力来支持它们。 2022年俄罗斯入侵乌克兰后，这一点变得更加清晰，当时中国和印度都在联合国放弃了对战争的谴责，并继续购买俄罗斯石油。

尽管这可能令七国集团国家感到担忧，但发达国家集团在全球舞台上仍然发挥着无与伦比的影响力。名义上，七国集团在全球经济中所占的份额（46万亿美元）仍然高于金砖国家（27.7万亿美元）。从协调对俄罗斯的制裁到向乌克兰提供军事援助，七国集团在财政和政治上仍然拥有重大影响力。

未来几十年，特别是当中国和印度被指定引领全球经济增长，同时努力解决本国内部人口问题时，随着这些国际集团争夺权力，世界秩序只会变得更加复杂和微妙。

病毒学创新：疫苗和抗病毒药物

COVID-19 大流行影响了全世界数百万人，并让人们重新关注病毒学（病毒的研究）。

然而，病毒造成的影响远远超出了导致 COVID-19 的 SARS-CoV-2 病毒。从肝炎到流感，共有 24 种病毒，每种病毒在全球范围内感染了超过8000 万人。

在MSCI的这张图表中，我们揭示了疫苗和抗病毒药物的创新以及相关的市场机会。

什么是病毒？

病毒是一种在活细胞内复制的微观传染原。它可能会导致宿主患病。由于突变，或者当病毒从动物转移到人类时，新病毒随时可能出现。

通过病毒学，科学家们不断寻找对抗传染病的新方法。有两种主要类型的抗感染药物：疫苗和抗病毒药物。

疫苗的快速创新

疫苗是旨在防止人们感染疾病或出现严重症状的物质。

过去三十年来，疫苗的数量急剧增加。仅从 2020 年到 2021 年，批准的疫苗或临床候选药物的数量就增长了13% 。

数据是时间快照，反映了所有已批准的疫苗（且未从市场上撤下）以及截至所述年份正在开发的所有疫苗（尚未取消试验）。

不仅如此，还可以缩短审批时间。 COVID-19 疫苗在 11 个月内获得批准，比 2000 年至 2020 年平均 10 年要快得多。

在疫情爆发和疫苗研发之间的这段时间内，抗病毒药物可以发挥至关重要的作用。

抗病毒药物：病毒学的第二道防线

抗病毒药物是减缓或预防病毒生长并治疗疾病症状的药物。对于没有相关疫苗的疾病，它们是特别重要的工具。

2021 年，批准的抗病毒药物数量几乎是 1995 年的六倍。不仅如此，抗病毒药物的用途已扩大到包括艾滋病毒、 COVID-19和许多其他疾病的潜在预防和治疗。

对同一病毒的潜在预防（预防）和治疗被视为单独的用途。数据是累积的，反映了所有已批准的抗病毒药物（且未从市场上撤下）以及所有已批准使用抗病毒药物的原因（尚未撤销）。

病毒学的创新以及未来发展的潜力正在推动行业不断发展。

扩大市场机会

随着机会的增加和审批时间的缩短，越来越多的公司正在进入市场。

在致力于开发新疫苗和抗病毒药物的过程中，公司正在针对 COVID-19 以外的许多疾病（例如呼吸道感染和败血症）进行临床试验。

病毒学正在引领许多突破性的技术和疗法，并一路改变医疗保健。

哪些国家最依赖煤炭？

这最初发布在Elements上。注册免费邮件列表，每周获得有关实际资产和资源大趋势的精美可视化。

近年来，全球能源政策和讨论一直关注能源系统脱碳在向净零转型过程中的重要性。

然而，尽管人们努力减少碳排放，化石燃料仍然占全球一次能源使用的80%以上，而煤炭作为世界上最便宜的能源燃料，也是能源相关二氧化碳排放的最大来源。

上图使用《世界能源统计评论》的数据显示了选定国家对化石燃料（尤其是煤炭）的依赖程度。

煤炭在新兴经济体中的重要性

煤炭是最大的发电来源，也是钢铁和水泥生产的主要燃料，使其成为气候和能源讨论的核心。

化石燃料仍然是一种负担得起且丰富的能源，特别是在需求迅速扩大的新兴经济体。

统计审查显示，南非是全球最依赖煤炭的国家，到2022年，煤炭将占其一次能源消费的69%。

2022年，全球煤炭消费量首次超过80亿吨，其中中国和印度是绝对数量最大的两个消费国。

仅中国电力行业就占全球煤炭消费量的三分之一。与此同时，自 2007 年以来，印度的煤炭消费量以每年 6% 的速度增长了一倍，预计将在未来几年引领煤炭消费的增长。

发达国家煤炭需求

与 2010 年代初期相比，美国的煤炭消耗量下降了近 50%。

通过《减少通货膨胀法案》(IRA) 等计划（其中包括近 3700 亿美元加速美国能源转型），美国的煤炭消费预计将保持下降趋势。

资料来源：BP 2023 年能源展望。该预测基于 BP 对 2050 年全球净零排放的设想。

欧盟也出现了同样的趋势。

例如，法国的一次能源消费中只有 2.5% 来自煤炭，这一比例仅为 2000 年代初的一半。

在欧洲最大经济体德国，煤炭仍占能源消费总量的18.9%（由于能源危机，比2021年略有增加）。然而，十年前的 2012 年，这一数字甚至更高，占一次能源使用的 24.9%。

随着发达国家煤炭消费量下降，但新兴经济体煤炭消费量保持稳定，国际能源署预计，煤炭需求将稳定在 2022 年的水平，直到 2025 年开始下降。

哪些国家最依赖煤炭？首先出现在视觉资本家。

美国的关键行业——包括休闲和健康社会服务——预计将成为未来十年增长最快的行业。

美国增长和衰退最快的行业（2021-2031P）一文首先出现在Visual Capitalist上。

美国各行业就业趋势（2021-2031）

劳动力总是在变化，以应对技术或社会变化。

因此，关注增长最快的行业可以帮助工人和企业掌握推动就业的关键趋势。

今天，我们通过美国劳工统计局(BLS) 对 2021 年至 2031 年间就业变化百分比来预测增长最快的行业以及下降最快的行业。

排名：就业变化增长最快的行业

活动主办方、代理商和经理位居增长最快行业之首，预计增长率高达 39%，到 2031 年将雇用超过 180,000 名员工。

游乐园和游乐场紧随其后，预计同期增长 38%，新增员工超过 60,000 名。排名第三的表演艺术行业将在下一个十年开始时拥有约 10 万名劳动力，比 2021 年增长 35%。

以下是美国劳工统计局预计 2021 年至 2031 年期间增长最快的行业的完整列表，按就业变化百分比排名。

注：服务业和其他行业包括信息、教育以及州和地方政府行业。

排名前三的行业均属于休闲和酒店业，该行业在增长最快的 20 个行业中占了 7 个。这种巨大的业绩反映的不仅仅是纯粹的增长，而是复苏，因为美国劳工统计局指出，休闲和酒店业受到了 COVID-19 大流行的过度影响，使其 2021 年的基线低于平常。

按就业变化百分比排名第四的是个人和家庭服务业，尽管实际上预计其总就业人数增长最快，到本十年末将增加 850,000 名新工人。由于美国人口老龄化导致对护理服务的需求增加，它是医疗保健和社会援助领域预计将大幅增长的三个行业之一。

不容错过的是计算机系统设计，由于对计算基础设施和 IT 安全的需求不断增长，该行业的就业人数预计将增长 20%。由于该行业的就业规模庞大，到 2021 年将有 230 万名工人，未来十年将增加近 50 万名工人。

排名：按就业变化排名下降最快的行业

预计到 2031 年，烟草制造行业的就业人数将减少 53%，从而使其本已很小的劳动力人数在本世纪末减少至仅 5,000 人。这种明显下降并不一定是由于吸烟习惯的减弱造成的，因为美国的卷烟销量在大流行期间有所上升。相反，该行业的进一步自动化可能会取代烟草制造员工。

另一个面临类似情况的行业是CD 和磁带制造行业，预计到 2031 年该行业的员工人数将减少 51%。

就业总量大幅萎缩的行业大多属于制造业。美国制造业的困境并不新鲜，但所呈现的行业多样性表明，导致整个行业衰退的因素有多种。

印刷、有线节目、报纸和图书出版商等一些行业面临着消费习惯的转变。

与此同时，纺织品、服装和家具制造等其他行业预计将因进一步自动化和将生产转移到国外而受到影响。

影响美国未来就业趋势的因素

值得注意的是，美国劳工统计局的这些预测是在 2022 年 9 月发布的。这意味着它们并没有反映出 ChatGPT 等生成式人工智能的快速崛起以及它们如何开始影响经济。

例如， 高盛最近的一份报告指出，未来 10 年，人工智能可能会在全球范围内取代 3 亿个工作岗位，几乎相当于美国的人口规模。

这使得人工智能或强大的人口趋势（例如人口增长放缓和劳动力老龄化）是否对决定未来就业格局最具影响力成为一个开放且重要的问题。

钴是某些类型电动汽车电池的重要组成部分，其全球生产格局已发生重大变化。

排名：世界顶级钴生产国

这最初发布在Elements上。注册免费邮件列表，每周获得有关实际资产和资源大趋势的精美可视化。

钴是电动汽车中使用的可充电锂离子电池的关键化学成分的重要组成部分，其全球生产格局已发生重大变化。

刚果民主共和国（DRC）长期以来一直是全球最大的钴生产国，2022年产量占全球的73%。

然而，根据钴研究所的数据，随着印度尼西亚快速扩张的镍工业的副产品钴产量的增加，刚果民主共和国的主导地位预计到 2030 年将下降至 57%。

2022年印度尼西亚成为第二大钴生产国

目前，印度尼西亚的钴产量占全球钴产量的近 5%，超过了澳大利亚和菲律宾等老牌生产国。

2022年，印度尼西亚的钴产量从2021年的2,700吨激增至近9,500吨，到2030年产量有可能增加十倍。
国家2022 年产量（吨）占总产量的百分比
刚果民主共和国144,936 73.3%
印度尼西亚9,454 4.8%
澳大利亚7,000 3.5%
菲律宾5,400 2.7%
古巴5,331 2.7%
俄罗斯3,500 人1.8%
马达加斯加3,500 人1.8%
加拿大3,100 1.6%
巴布亚新几内亚3,060 人1.5%
土耳其2,300 1.2%
其他10,210 5.2%
全部的197,791 100.0%

由于四舍五入，百分比加起来可能不会等于 100。

全球钴产量总计达到 197,791 吨，其中刚果民主共和国的产量略低于 145,000 吨。

电动汽车行业是钴的最大消费者，约占总需求的40%。预计到 2030 年，电动汽车行业的指数级增长将推动全球钴需求翻一番。

尽管钴生产的转变引人注目，但也并非没有挑战。钴价暴跌，今年下跌近 30% 至每磅 13.90 美元，严重影响了刚果民主共和国。

此外，由于努力减少钴在电池中的使用，钴的长期前景可能面临障碍，部分原因是与刚果民主共和国手工钴开采相关的人权问题以及相关的童工和侵犯人权行为。

在华盛顿联邦法院 2021 年的一项裁决中，谷歌母公司 Alphabet、苹果、戴尔、微软和特斯拉免于集体诉讼，这些诉讼声称它们对刚果钴矿涉嫌使用童工负有责任。

钴的未来

尽管人们不断努力在电池应用中替代钴，但预计在不久的将来钴仍将是整个电池供应链的重要原材料。

预计到 2030 年，钴需求量将增加一倍以上，达到 388,000 吨。

品牌价值可能是任何公司无形资产的重要组成部分。

专利和品牌等非实物资产对公司整体价值的影响越来越大。 2020 年的分析发现，无形资产占标准普尔 500 指数市值的90% ，自 1995 年以来增加了 22 个百分点。

该图根据Brand Finance的年度排名显示了 2023 年全球 100 个最有价值品牌，说明了品牌资产在公司市场地位中所扮演的角色。

Amazon ranks number one globally with its brand valued at $299 billion. As a market leader in online retail, it has strong brand loyalty in its B2C segment which generates its largest share of revenue , and is a key player in cloud services for its B2B platforms.

Apple is in close second with a $298 billion brand. It's important to note that both tech giants brands fell in value from last year, as supply chain disruptions, labor market constraints, and slower forecasted revenue impacted their brands.

Other big tech brands Google (#3) and Microsoft (#4) were next in the ranking. Korean conglomerate Samsung (#6) was the highest-ranking firm based outside of America.

Overall, the top tech brands were worth a combined $891 billion largely thanks to the outsized influence of Apple, Microsoft, and Samsung.

After retail and media, the banking sector still held significant brand sway at $467 billion. Automobiles rounded out the top five sectors at $397 billion, led by companies like Tesla and Mercedes-Benz.

The Fastest Rising Brands in 2023

While some brands such as Apple and Amazon fell in value over the last year, others have increased their brand value.

Below, we show the fastest rising brands across the top 500 around the world:

Rank姓名Brand Value % Change (2022-2023)
1 BYD 57%
2 ConocoPhillips 56%
3 Maersk 53%
4 LinkedIn 49%
5 Christian Dior 46%
6 Tesla 44%
7 ADP 44%
8 United Airlines 42%
9 Instagram 42%
10 Equinor 40%

BYD , a leading electric vehicle (EV) firm in China, jumped the sharpest. Focused on budget EVs and backed by Warren Buffett, it has become a growing competitor to Tesla, and is the second-largest producer of lithium-ion batteries globally.

Energy firm ConocoPhillips saw the second-largest gain in brand value, driven by its focus on energy transition fuels, cutting production emissions, and lowering supply costs.

Following a series of difficult years for the airline industry , United Airline’s brand value increased 42% as travel demand accelerated.

As the economic landscape continues to shift, the value of these brands will shift as well.

Where does this data come from?

Source : Brand Finance Global 500 Report

Important note: The values shown above are brand value calculations as opposed to market capitalization. See below for more details.

How is brand value calculated? Generally speaking, the methodology for calculating “brand value” is a formula that is as follows:

Brand Strength (BSI) x Brand Royalty Rate x Brand Revenues = Brand Value

Brand Strength Index (BSI) looks at brand investment, brand equity, and brand performance. The brand royalty rate is determined based on sector. Lastly, forecast brand-specific revenues are determined based on the proportion of parent company revenues attributable to the brand in question. Brand value itself is discounted to net present value.

We recommend visiting page 83 of the report to view the full explanation of the methodology.

Where are various types of livestock concentrated globally? And how do regional habits influence animal husbandry?

The post Mapped: Global Livestock Distribution and Density appeared first on Visual Capitalist .

;

Click to view this graphic in a higher-resolution .


Mapped: Global Livestock Distribution and Density

Combined together, meat, dairy, and eggs make up nearly 18% of the average person's diet .

But in order for these meat and animal products to reach consumers, a vast global livestock industry—one supporting the livelihoods of 1.3 billion people globally—operates in fields and farms largely unseen from major cities.

So where are the various types of livestock concentrated in the world? And how do national consumption habits influence animal husbandry?

These maps from Adam Symington help to answer these questions, using the Gridded Livestock of the World database from the UN Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), which models livestock densities from 2010 around the world.

Chicken, Beef, and Pork Livestock Density

As a starting point, it's worth noting that the above map of all livestock might seem reminiscent to a human population density map.

Though there is definite correlation, especially when it comes to natural obstacles for both humans and livestock like deserts, forests, and mountain ranges, the concentration of livestock spreads far further than the densest human cities.

We dive into each category of livestock below.

Chicken Livestock Density

The UN FAO estimates that the world produced more than 121 million tonnes of chicken meat in 2021, making it the world's most harvested meat. Chicken eggs are also estimated to account for 93% of the world's 86 million tonnes of poultry eggs .

These numbers and the map below help illustrate the sheer number of chickens needed to support the world's appetite for chicken goods.

Click to view this graphic in a higher-resolution .

Just by glancing at the heatmap map of chicken distribution, two things stand out clearly. First is how ubiquitous chickens are, with a high density of chicken livestock in almost all of the world's populated regions.

But the map also gives us insight into where most farms are located. In the US for example, Southern states including Georgia, North Carolina, Alabama, Mississippi, and Arkansas are major chicken producers. Likewise in countries like Brazil and China , the chicken industry can be seen continuing inland far beyond the more populated coastal regions.

Pig Livestock Density

Shifting attention to pig livestock, we see densities begin to concentrate in a few specific regions.

Click to view this graphic in a higher-resolution .

China stands out on the map with large concentrations of pig livestock, which comes as no surprise given the country is far and away the world's top producer of pork .

Also clear is the regionality of pork consumption. The US has a strong concentration of pig livestock in the Midwest, while Central Europe has multiple countries with a noted history of pork consumption including Germany and Poland . Finally, partially thanks to its premium production of jamón ibérico , the country of Spain also stands out.

On the flip side, there is a clear absence of pig-rearing in countries of Islamic faith , across North Africa, the Middle East, and Central Asia, reflecting their religious prohibition.

Cattle Livestock Density

In contrast, the map of cattle distribution more closely mirrors chicken distribution, though its footprint is considerably wider.

Click to view this graphic in a higher-resolution .

Major cow byproducts like milk and leather, as well as the sheer strength of cattle, make them vital livestock even for countries that don't consume a lot of beef. The FAO estimates that the world produced 746 million tonnes of raw cattle milk in 2021 alone.

On the map, the largest producers of cattle stand out. India for example is the top producer of milk and the fourth-largest producer of cattle meat, and has a high density of cattle throughout populated and agricultural regions. Brazil , also a top four producer of cattle meat and milk, has pockets of high density cattle regions inland, notably encroaching into the Amazon rainforest .

Meanwhile, the US is the world's largest producer of beef and second largest of milk, but it does this with a more distributed cattle population throughout the country's landmass, and fewer high-density hot spots.

Mapping Duck, Sheep, and Goat Livestock

Although chicken, beef, and pork are the most common types of livestock globally, there are other kinds of animals that have much more regional distributions.

In the following maps, you'll see livestock concentrated in just a few places, usually following unique cultural connections to these animals.

Duck Livestock Density

Compared to chicken above, ducks are much less widespread in farming and usage.

Click to view this graphic in a higher-resolution .

China is the runaway king when it comes to both duck livestock and meat production. The country accounted for 78% of global duck meat production in 2021—but distant runners up Vietnam and France also show strong concentrations of duck.

Perhaps surprising to some is the strong foothold duck has in Bangladesh . Farmers in the country have embraced duck over the past decades as both a more profitable bird, and more recently, as an adaptation to climate change.

Sheep Livestock Density

Moving to sheep , which provide meat, milk, and wool, we once again have a widespread global population. However, the regions with the highest densities have wildly changed.

Click to view this graphic in a higher-resolution .

Sheep can be seen in higher numbers throughout North and Central Africa, the Middle East, and Central Asia. Australia , New Zealand , and the UK also stand out in their regions for higher concentrations of sheep.

Goat Livestock Density

Click to view this graphic in a higher-resolution .

Goats have their highest concentrations in North India, North China, Mongolia , and many countries across Africa. Nigeria in particular has a strong goat farming industry.

The Future of the Global Livestock Industry

How is the livestock industry expected to change, going forward?

For starters, the UN estimates that global meat consumption is projected to rise 14% by 2030, driven primarily by population growth. That growth will occur unevenly, from a 30% jump in Africa to a 0.4% in Europe.

At the same time, emissions from the livestock sector have increasingly come under fire in recent years, and the industry is projected to register a 5% increase by 2030.

All these factors, alongside growth in plant-based meat and cultured meat, may change livestock distribution over the coming decade.

Visualizing the Top Economies in the World

According to a recent report from Goldman Sachs , the balance of global economic power is projected to shift dramatically in the coming decades.

In the graphic above, we've created a bump chart that provides a historical and predictive overview of the world's top 15 economies at several milestones: 1980, 2000, 2022, and Goldman Sachs projections for 2050 and 2075.

Projections and Highlights for 2050

The following table shows the projected top economies in the world for 2050. All figures represent real GDP projections, based on 2021 USD.

A major theme of the past several decades has been China and India’s incredible growth. For instance, between 2000 and 2022, India jumped eight spots to become the fifth largest economy, surpassing the UK and France .

By 2050, Goldman Sachs believes that the weight of global GDP will shift even more towards Asia. While this is partly due to Asia outperforming previous forecasts, it is also due to BRICS nations underperforming.

Notably, Indonesia will become the fourth biggest economy by 2050, surpassing Brazil and Russia as the largest emerging market. Indonesia is the world's largest archipelagic state, and currently has the fourth largest population at 277 million.

The Top Economies in the World in 2075

The following table includes the underlying numbers for 2075. Once again, figures represent real GDP projections, based on 2021 USD.

Projecting further to 2075 reveals a drastically different world order, with Nigeria , Pakistan , and Egypt breaking into the top 10. A major consideration in these estimates is rapid population growth, which should result in a massive labor force across all three nations.

Meanwhile, European economies will continue to slip further down the rankings. Germany, which was once the world's third largest economy, will sit at ninth behind Brazil.

It should also be noted that China , India , and the US are expected to have similar GDPs by this time, suggesting somewhat equal economic power. As a result, how these nations choose to engage with one another is likely to shape the global landscape in ways that have far-reaching implications.

How much water do we have, and which countries use the most? This visual breaks down global water distribution and withdrawals by countries.

;

Understanding the Global Supply of Water

As the world's population and its agricultural needs have grown, so too has the demand for water, putting the world's supply of water under the microscope.

A century ago, freshwater consumption was six times lower than in modern times. This increase in demand and usage has resulted in rising stress on freshwater resources and further depletion of reservoirs.

This graphic by Chesca Kirkland uses insights from Our World in Data to break down water supply and also withdrawals per capita. The latter measures the quantity of water taken from both groundwater and freshwater sources for agricultural, industrial, or domestic use.

How Much Water Do We Have?

Many people know that more than 70% of the Earth's surface is water. That's 326 million trillion gallons of water, yet humanity still faces a tight supply.这是为什么？

It's because 97% of this water is saline and unfit for consumption. Of the remaining 3% of freshwater, about two-thirds are locked away in the form of snow, glaciers, and polar ice caps. Meanwhile, just under a third of freshwater is found in fast-depleting groundwater resources.

That leaves just 1% of global freshwater as “easily” sourced supply from rainfall as well as freshwater reservoirs including rivers and lakes.

Per Capita Water Withdrawals

Any look at a world map of rivers and lakes will reveal that fresh water distribution is highly uneven across different regions of the world.

Yet developed and developing countries alike require a lot of water for both commercial and personal use. Agriculture use alone accounts for an estimated 70% of the world's available freshwater.

Below we can see how water withdrawals per capita have grown over the past decades, using the latest available data from each.

Many of the countries with the largest water withdrawals per capita are located in the arid deserts of Central Asia, including top-ranked Turkmenistan at 5,753 cubic meters of annual water withdrawals per person in 2005.

And for developing countries with high water usage, from Turkmenistan to Guyana , most of their water withdrawals are for agriculture. For example, an estimated 95% of available water in Turkmenistan goes towards agriculture.

Developed nations like Finland , New Zealand and the US also withdraw tons of water, at more than 1,000 cubic meters annually per person, but their uses are notably different. In the United States , for example, 41% of water withdrawals in 2015 went to thermoelectric power generation, while 37% went towards irrigation and livestock. For Finland, on the other hand, 80% of water was used for industrial production.

Most of the countries with lower water withdrawals per capita, meanwhile, are concentrated in Africa. They include very populated countries, such as Nigeria and Kenya , which both withdrew around 75 cubic meters of water per person in 2015 and 2010 respectively. This also highlights the continent's water accessibility and infrastructure issues.

Bridging the Water Inequity Gap

Over the years, various initiatives have emerged to mitigate the world's water inequality gap.

Efforts include promoting water conservation practices, investing in efficient irrigation systems , and enhancing water infrastructure in regions most affected by scarcity.

Some nations in arid climates with coastal access, such as Saudi Arabia , are also converting ocean salt water to fresh water through desalination plants.

Singers, athletes, actors and Kardashians—here are the most followed Instagram accounts and their estimated earnings per sponsored post.

Most Followed Instagram Accounts and Sponsored Post Costs

Instagram is not only one of the biggest social media platforms, it's also one of the most profitable for high profile creators.

Despite having fewer users than platforms like Facebook and YouTube, Instagram's higher engagement rate gives it one of the highest advertising costs . In 2023, average ad prices on Instagram were estimated at $3.56 cost per click , ahead of every platform except LinkedIn.

For the celebrities with the most followers on Instagram, and the brands trying to profit from their followers, that translates into million-dollar costs for some sponsored posts. Pablo Alvarez has visualized Instagram's biggest accounts, and their estimated earnings per sponsored post, using HopperHQ data from September 2022.

Calculating The Earnings Per Sponsored Post

It's easy to assume that the most followed Instagram accounts make the most money on sponsored posts, but that appears to be only partially true.

In conducting research for the dataset, HopperHQ utilized both publicly available data and reports and privately researched statistics to measure the impact of different factors:

  • Number of followers
  • Levels of engagement (legitimate views, likes & comments)
  • Influencer's category (sports, music, acting, etc.)
  • Audience makeup
  • Influencer status (previous endorsements, number of endorsements, etc.)

And though the number of followers was the biggest influencing factor, some stars earned more from followers than others.

Costs of the Most Followed Instagram Accounts in 2022

The most followed person on Facebook and Instagram, soccer star Cristiano Ronaldo leads the list of the most expensive Instagram accounts in 2022 for sponsored content.

It's estimated that the former Manchester United and Real Madrid star was able to charge an estimated $2.4 million per sponsored post in 2022. With 442 million followers at the time of calculation, Ronaldo was estimated to charge nearly half a million dollars per post more than the next person on the list.

But the most commonly followed celebrities in the top 20 were musicians with household names, including Ariana Grande, Beyoncé, and Taylor Swift. They accounted for 45% of the most followed accounts.
